entry.title: Prince Philip (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Prince Philip (pictured) was the first member of the British royal family to fly in a helicopter?

entry.title: Raḥamim (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the 1910–1916 publication Raḥamim was the first newspaper in the Judeo-Tajik language?

entry.title: Dick Harris (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that football player Dick Harris was selected in professional drafts four times, including twice as a first-round pick, but never played professionally?

entry.title: a Merseyside flat (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Pulp singer Jarvis Cocker helped fundraise to save a Merseyside flat that has been called "the first example of outsider art to be nationally listed"?

entry.title: Butterfly Theater (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that in 1911 the Butterfly Theater featured a pipe organ worth $10,000 (equivalent to $327,000 in 2023)?

entry.title: V. Kerry Smith (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that environmental economist V. Kerry Smith has been described as a "Renaissance Man of Economics"?

entry.title: to respond to a diss against him (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that a year after objecting to the unauthorised use of his own AI-generated vocals, Drake used vocals of other rappers generated that way to respond to a diss against him?

entry.title: Hilda Hope McMaugh (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that in 1919 nurse Hilda Hope McMaugh became the first Australian woman to qualify as a pilot?

entry.title: a Florida TV station (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that employees of a Florida TV station joked that their studio building would survive "as long as the termites don't stop holding hands"?
